an3.30:1.1: “These three individuals are found in the world.
an3.30:1.3: One with upside-down wisdom, one with wisdom on their lap, and one with widespread wisdom.
an3.30:1.4: And who is the individual with upside-down wisdom?
an3.30:1.5: It’s an individual who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:1.6: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:1.7: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:1.8: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:1.9: It’s like when a pot full of water is tipped over, so the water drains out and doesn’t stay.
an3.30:1.10: In the same way, an individual often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:1.11: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:1.12: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t apply the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, or end.
an3.30:1.13: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:1.14: This is called an individual with upside-down wisdom.
an3.30:2.1: And who is the individual with wisdom on their lap?
an3.30:2.2: It’s an individual who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:2.3: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:2.4: While sitting there, that person applies the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:2.5: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:2.6: It’s like a person who has different kinds of food crammed on their lap—
an3.30:2.7: such as sesame, rice, sweets, or jujube—
an3.30:2.8: so that if they get up from the seat without mindfulness, everything gets scattered.
an3.30:2.9: In the same way, an individual often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:2.10: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:2.11: While sitting there, that person applies the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:2.12: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:2.13: This is called an individual with wisdom on their lap.
an3.30:3.1: And who is the individual with widespread wisdom?
an3.30:3.2: It’s an individual who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:3.3: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:3.4: While sitting there, they apply the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:3.5: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:3.6: It’s like when a pot full of water is set straight, so the water stays and doesn’t drain out.
an3.30:3.7: In the same way, an individual often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:3.8: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:3.9: While sitting there, they apply the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:3.10: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:3.11: This is called an individual with widespread wisdom.
an3.30:3.12: These are the three individuals found in the world.
